stories.headline: A solemn salute
stories.summary: Cmdr. Roy Taylor of American Legion Post 800 salutes during the Memorial Day parade ceremony at McKinley Park Memorial Day on Monday, honoring fallen soldiers with ceremonial respect.

stories.headline: Layoffs leave violence outreach group reeling
stories.summary: Englewood's violence outreach group led by Pha'Tal Perkins is struggling after recent layoffs and shifts in DOJ priorities. The team, active in responding to shootings and supporting community violence victims, faces challenges as federal grants end, causing staffing losses. Despite setbacks, the organization continues its efforts but highlights the strain from reduced funding and the impact on public safety programs, particularly for children and families affected by violence.

stories.headline: New aid system begins in Gaza
stories.summary: A U.S.-backed Gaza Humanitarian Foundation has launched a new aid distribution system following objections at the United Nations. The new approach aims to improve assistance flow amid the ongoing conflict in Gaza, where recent Israeli strikes have killed at least 52 people.

stories.headline: Brightest minds struggle to find work
stories.summary: Research and development job openings are declining due to Trump administration cuts to government agencies, contractors, and universities. Scientific research and development postings are down 18% since Trump took office, impacting highly skilled workers' employment prospects.

stories.headline: Sacrifice of fallen soldiers honored at Arlington
stories.summary: Memorial Day ceremonies at Arlington National Cemetery included President Trump paying tribute to fallen service members. Trump reflected on the sacrifices made and the enduring legacy of the nation’s warriors while emphasizing political points. The solemn event also honored stories of individual family members, in a ceremony that commemorated over 400,000 interred veterans and Gold Star families.

stories.headline: Plan draws pushback from polluters
stories.summary: Mayor Brandon Johnson proposes new land-use policies aimed at reforming environmental standards to reduce pollution in Black and Latino communities. While environmentalists support the move, heavy industry advocates express concerns over additional requirements for new industrial developments. The proposal includes establishing a community-based environmental justice advisory board and mandates for new projects to conduct health assessments. Supporters argue it will not significantly impact businesses without substantial environmental footprints.

stories.headline: Continuing education credits are latest perk
stories.summary: State legislators who are also lawyers in Illinois will now receive up to 12 continuing education credits annually for showing up to work in the General Assembly. The new benefit, effective from January 1, 2025, follows a Supreme Court rule change and is endorsed by multiple lawmakers. The perk allows lawyer-legislators to collect credits through legislative sessions or committee hearings, easing their requirements to maintain law licenses.

stories.headline: Jan. 6 defendants still face legal issues
stories.summary: Despite pardons issued by former President Trump, six defendants tied to the Jan. 6, 2021 U.S. Capitol attack continue to face legal issues related to their cases. Issues such as heightened security screening and complications involving formal legal proceedings persist for these individuals. Defense attorney Christopher Macchiaroli explains that many defendants have had trouble fulfilling obligations like background checks and applying for jobs, and some cases are being dismissed with prejudice depending on judge discretion.

stories.headline: Trump seeks reset with new Syrian leader
stories.summary: President Trump is working to reset relations with Syria by engaging with the newly prominent Syrian President Ahmad al-Sharaa, who has distanced himself from al Qaeda. Al-Sharaa aims to foster economic development and influence Damascus to reshape its political stance. This approach intends to curb Iranian influence and promote peace in the region, with Washington hoping for positive developments following Trump's May 14 meeting with al-Sharaa.

stories.headline: Capitalism flows where diplomats can't reach
stories.summary: Private money and sanctions strategy constitute a key part of Trump's foreign policy playbook toward Syria and the broader Middle East. Despite sanctions imposed by the Trump administration, issues persist with foreign policy effectiveness. President Trump met with Syrian leader Ahmad al-Sharaa to announce easing some sanctions, but many challenges remain as Syria struggles to return to normal business and political relations.

stories.headline: GOLD RUSH FIZZLES: Trump drops plan to check on Fort Knox inventory
stories.summary: President Trump abandoned his plan to personally inspect the U.S. Bullion Depository at Fort Knox in Kentucky. The Trump brand's earlier association with gold faced a turning point when the idea of a physical audit at Fort Knox was discussed but ultimately dropped. Annual audits confirm the gold is still present, counteracting conspiracy theories. Trump and his administration have been involved in public discussions about the nation's gold reserves, but the visit did not materialize.

stories.headline: Trump tariffs rev up auto sales while reshaping global market
stories.summary: President Trump's tariffs on foreign-made cars and parts, although only weeks old, are significantly impacting global auto markets. Asian countries are contemplating reducing export-heavy sectors to the U.S., while American consumers face higher prices and shifts in automobile production back to the U.S. The tariffs, effective from March 25, aim to protect the domestic auto industry but introduce uncertainty and concerns about long-term economic effects.

stories.headline: Journey to U.S. Was Perilous. So Is Trip Home.
stories.summary: Approximately 40 people in Panama's Caribbean Coast risk their lives crossing dangerous terrain to reach the U.S. and face challenges such as kidnapping, crossing jungle paths, and hostile immigration enforcement. These Venezuelan migrants endure life-threatening conditions in hopes of a better future, with their journey marked by both physical danger and uncertainty.

stories.headline: Even in War, Hot-Dog-Loving Ukrainians Savor Taste of the West
stories.summary: Amidst the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, citizens including soldiers enjoy simple pleasures such as American-style hot dogs and particular food items symbolizing Western culture. Despite the war, these tastes serve as a morale boost and cultural connection to the West. The story highlights the human side of war and how food becomes a medium of comfort and defiance.

stories.headline: Son of Harlem Who Ascended To 23-Term Pillar of the House
stories.summary: Charles B. Rangel, former dean of New York's congressional delegation, passed away at age 94. Rangel was known as a powerful and influential legislator and became one of the longest-serving members of the House of Representatives with 23 terms. His career was marked by both notable achievements and several controversies, but his impact on Harlem and American politics remains significant.

stories.headline: Delay in Tariffs Spurs New Push for U.S.-E.U. Deal
stories.summary: Trade talks between the United States and the European Union resumed after President Trump delayed tariffs on the European Union by 50 percent. Despite the restart, neither side is showing signs of budging on key issues. The talks aim for a trade deal by early July. Officials and spokespersons from both sides highlighted ongoing challenges and the need for careful negotiation to avoid further trade disruption.

stories.headline: Embassy Aide Quietly Buried Back in Israel
stories.summary: Beit Zayit, Israel — Weeks after the tragic death of former American embassy aide Jonathan Lischinsky in Gaza, he was given a quiet burial in Israel alongside a small community. Lischinsky had come to Gaza to introduce a truce proposal and was killed amid escalating violence. His death raises concerns about the ongoing conflict and its human toll, further complicated by tense relations between Israel and regional players.

stories.headline: Allies of Israel Raise Pressure To Cease War
stories.summary: As the war in Gaza surpasses 18 months with widespread criticism from foreign leaders, Israel's closest allies including the United States, Britain, and France have increased pressure on Israeli leadership to cease hostilities. President Trump has openly criticized Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's approach and advocated for an end to the conflict to prevent further suffering and destabilization in the region.

stories.headline: Where Chicano meets Vietnamese
stories.summary: Vietnamese barber Phuoc Loc embraces Chicano culture through his barbershop in Ho Chi Minh City, blending Mexican American cultural elements with local traditions to create a unique community focused on family and heritage.

stories.headline: For some, medical debt will disappear
stories.summary: Los Angeles County is aiding residents by paying off millions owed in medical debt through a program launched in partnership with the nonprofit Undue Medical Debt, aiming to relieve financial stress for vulnerable residents.

stories.headline: Data show deeper water losses
stories.summary: Research based on NASA data reveals that the Colorado River Basin's reservoirs are experiencing significant decline, with groundwater depletion rates alarmingly high. This has serious implications for regional water supply and agriculture.

stories.headline: Girl who is facing deportation requires lifesaving care in U.S.
stories.summary: Deysi Vargas, a young girl with a severe health condition requiring 24-hour medical care, has been granted humanitarian entry to the U.S. but faces the threat of deportation. The family seeks legal status to continue lifesaving treatments and avoid separation.

stories.headline: FEMA urged to reinstate state's quake grants
stories.summary: Senator Adam Schiff is advocating for the reinstatement of federal funds that were canceled by the Trump administration, which supported earthquake retrofits in California. The grants are crucial for vulnerable apartment buildings and could prevent deaths during earthquakes.

stories.headline: MercyOne replacing DM anesthesia firm with California provider
stories.summary: MercyOne Des Moines has signed a new anesthesia service provider partnership with Vitutiy, a California-based specialty physician group, to provide anesthesia care at MercyOne’s central Iowa locations, including downtown Des Moines hospitals. This new partnership comes after MercyOne ended its previous agreement with Medical Center Anesthesiologists, a Des Moines-area anesthesia provider, following a contract disagreement. MercyOne’s goal is to maintain excellent service in the transition, with Vitutiy taking over on May 31, allowing patient care to continue without interruption.

stories.headline: Iowa taps surplus to plug $900M budget gap
stories.summary: Iowa lawmakers are using the state's budget surplus and Taxpayer Relief Fund to fill a $900 million gap in the coming fiscal year's budget. Republicans passed the budget before the 2025 legislative session adjourned, setting a $9.42 billion budget for fiscal year 2026, an increase of 5.3% from the current year. Expected tax revenue is reduced due to GOP-backed changes to the flat income tax rate. The state will use about $8.51 billion in revenue and tap $463.6 million from the Taxpayer Relief Fund, which will reduce its balance from $4.03 billion to $3.65 billion. The state surplus will also decline. Legislators emphasize careful budgeting to avoid using one-time monies for ongoing expenses.

stories.headline: Iowans brace for cuts to Medicaid, SNAP
stories.summary: Health care officials, social safety net providers and other advocates in Iowa are bracing for impact after Congress' Republican majority passed major cuts to Medicaid and the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program as part of President Donald Trump’s budget priorities. The bill, the House 215-214, now heads to the Senate and proposes an estimated $625 billion cut from public insurance programs covering more than 71 million Americans, including reductions in food stamps that would total up to $300 billion over the next decade. Iowa lawmakers, advocates, and affected families express concern about the lack of preparation and the detrimental social impact of these cuts.

stories.headline: Airbnb cracking down on disruptive parties
stories.summary: Airbnb has announced it will take stronger measures to prevent disruptive parties after rolling out an 'anti-party technology' across the U.S. system. This initiative is in effect for upcoming holidays including Memorial Day and the Fourth of July to ensure peaceful guest experiences.

stories.headline: Immigration crackdown unnerves Cuban exiles
stories.summary: Immigration officials in South Florida have detained a 71-year-old Cuban exile amid a broader campaign to apprehend Cuban officials linked to deportation efforts. The crackdown has raised fears within the Cuban exile community of political retaliation and uncertainty over immigration enforcement, especially given the ongoing mass deportations under President Trump's administration. The issue highlights the tension within the Cuban exile community and concerns over their safety.

stories.headline: The 2028 podcast primary is underway
stories.summary: Podcasts featuring political figures such as Governor Gavin Newsom, Andy Beshear, and Gretchen Whitmer are engaging younger audiences as potential contenders for the 2028 presidential primary. These podcasts have gained traction following President Donald Trump's lead in using that medium in the 2024 campaign.

stories.headline: Trump honors fallen soldiers at Arlington
stories.summary: President Donald Trump attended a Memorial Day ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery, paying tribute to the nation's veterans and recognizing those who are considered America's bravest. The event emphasized honoring service members who sacrificed their lives.

stories.headline: City to realign Central Avenue for development
stories.summary: The Decatur City Council is planning to realign Central Avenue Southwest and upgrade Beltline Place to incentivize economic growth, including a potential new hotel and restaurant. City Engineer Carl Prewitt and other officials outlined the design to straighten the avenue for better public street standards. Council voted to hire a company for project engineering with an estimated cost of $1.5 million. The plan aims to improve traffic flow and attract commercial development in the area, with involvement from local leaders and potential tenants.

stories.headline: More than barbecues
stories.summary: The Memorial Day event at Founders Park and the Gold Star Memorial in Decatur featured numerous flags and ceremonies honoring fallen veterans. Emma Landrum of Priceville shared her dedication to the cause through her involvement with the Forgotten Heroes Project, highlighting the importance of remembering fallen soldiers and service members. The event included wreath laying and a keynote address by Major Gen. Frank J. Lozano, emphasizing the communal respect and remembrance for veterans during this day.

stories.headline: State poised to require Ten Commandments in classrooms
stories.summary: Texas is considering a bill that would require public schools to display a 16-by-20-inch poster copy of the Ten Commandments in every pre-K through 12th-grade classroom. The GOP-led House passed the bill 58 to 49 despite opposition citing concerns about violating students' freedom of religion and potentially alienating non-Christian students. The legislation, supported by Republicans including Rep. Candy Noble and Sen. Bill 10, awaits the governor's signature to become law.

stories.headline: Detained kids lack attorneys at court
stories.summary: Only 1 in 37 children appearing in court at the Houston Gessner Immigration Court had legal representation. Many of these children, some as young as 6, lack attorneys due to funding challenges faced by organizations like the Galveston Houston Immigrant Representation Project. The Trump administration's policy changes and a halted contract with the Acacia Center for Justice have exacerbated the problem. Advocacy groups warn that this lack of legal support severely impacts children's rights and case outcomes in immigration proceedings.

stories.headline: Taps signals solemn Memorial Day tribute
stories.summary: A ceremony at Houston National Cemetery honored fallen military servicemembers on Memorial Day with a traditional taps bugle call. Steve Walker, a 71-year-old volunteer, led the taps call as dozens gathered to remember those who sacrificed their lives. The event included placing flags and wreaths, with speakers emphasizing the importance of remembering and honoring veterans' sacrifices.

stories.headline: AP exam pass rates on rise in HISD
stories.summary: Access to testing and courses in the Houston Independent School District has improved since the pandemic, boosting AP exam pass rates. The number of students taking AP exams nearly doubled to 40 courses over the past three decades, with pass rates rising despite a slight decline in number of students taking the exams from 2018-2019 to 2023-2024. District investments and growth in AP program participation have helped raise the share of students passing at least one AP exam from 38% to nearly half.

stories.headline: Study: 'Invisible threat' sinking large U.S. cities
stories.summary: A study published by the British journal Nature Cities reveals that 25 of the 28 most populous U.S. cities are sinking at various rates due to groundwater extraction, a phenomenon called subsidence or the "invisible threat." For example, more than 72% of Boston is sinking by up to 3 millimeters a year. Subsidence is caused by water withdrawal from aquifers made of fine-grained sediments and is exacerbated in coastal cities by natural sediment compaction and human activities such as mining and pumping of oil and gas.

stories.headline: Electrical upgrades incoming from Avangrid
stories.summary: Avangrid, the parent company of New York State Electric and Gas and Rochester Gas and Electric, announced a $41 million investment to modernize the electrical grid infrastructure in Ithaca. This investment is part of a larger $20 billion effort to improve New York's energy systems, including new substations and transmission lines. The upgrades aim to enhance grid reliability and capacity, benefiting over 42,000 customers and supporting future growth.

stories.headline: Future of Wells College forum is scheduled
stories.summary: The Cleveland Commission for Wells College will hold a public forum via Zoom to discuss the future of the Wells College campus in Aurora, which closed after the 2024 spring term. The commission believes reopening the campus as a liberal arts college is viable and is currently seeking bids to purchase the campus. The commission also has plans to raise funds and engage with community organizations to support the revitalization efforts.

stories.headline: Brightline offers discounts on South Florida, Orlando trains
stories.summary: Brightline is offering discounted fares on its train routes between Boca Raton, West Palm Beach, and Orlando. These discounts reduce the cost of typical one-way tickets by several dollars, making trips more affordable than driving or gas expenses. Special promotions include one-way tickets between West Palm Beach and Orlando with prices significantly reduced from the usual fare, along with savings for public school teachers and university students using the train. The discounts aim to encourage increased ridership on the private passenger rail system in South Florida and beyond.

stories.headline: WPB, Palm Beach 2nd in ‘wealth hub’ report
stories.summary: West Palm Beach and Palm Beach ranked second nationwide as 'wealth hubs' for affluent households migrating to Palm Beach County after the pandemic, according to Henley and Partners' 2025 USA Wealth Report. The report highlights a significant increase in millionaires between 2014 and 2024, with the area becoming a prized retirement spot for millionaires, especially from New York and California. The two cities combined hold numerous millionaires, indicating their status as a leading wealth center globally, following Scottsdale, Arizona.

stories.headline: Activists preserving, sharing U.S. history
stories.summary: At the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad Visitor Center in Church Creek, Maryland, activists and historians are emphasizing the importance of acknowledging the true history of racial injustice, slavery, and segregation in America. This movement faces challenges from the Trump administration's efforts to defund and alter diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives and historical representations, which some view as revisionist. The bust of Harriet Tubman at the center, which prompts visitors to connect with the scars of history, symbolizes the ongoing struggle to preserve accurate and honest historical narratives.

stories.headline: Democrats' struggles revive the debate over word choice
stories.summary: Democrats face a debate over language choice to appear inclusive but not elitist. The use of terms like 'oligarchs' versus 'rich people' reflects tensions in appealing to voters amidst the era of President Donald Trump. Some Democrats believe that simple, clear language that resonates with working-class voters is key to regaining trust and electoral support.

stories.headline: Ukraine fears crack in air shield
stories.summary: Ukraine is growing concerned about its ability to secure U.S.-made Patriot air defense systems amid resistance from the Biden administration to send additional systems. Russia continues to attack Ukraine with drones and missiles, and Ukraine's air defense missed many strikes over the recent Memorial Day weekend. Officials fear that only existing Patriot batteries can counter Russian missiles, highlighting Ukraine's urgent need for more robust defense.

stories.headline: Congressman was a powerful voice for Harlem
stories.summary: Charles B. Rangel, the first Black House Ways and Means chair, passed away at age 94. Rangel was a strong advocate for Harlem and its diverse communities, serving 46 years in Congress. Despite some controversies that led him to relinquish his chairmanship, he was known for his dedication to fighting poverty, supporting interventionist military policies, and protecting his constituents' interests.

stories.headline: Details of E. coli surge not disclosed
stories.summary: Colton George, a 9-year-old boy from Indiana, fell sick with E. coli after eating contaminated lettuce. The outbreak has affected nearly 90 people across 15 states, leading to a federal lawsuit against the lettuce grower. However, details about the source and investigation were not publicly disclosed due to a Trump administration memo limiting regulatory transparency, raising concerns about food safety.

stories.headline: Gaza under fire as aid group says it has begun food delivery
stories.summary: Israeli airstrikes on Gaza hit a school shelter, killing at least 30 people, including Verd al-Sheikh Khalil’s family. Despite the violence, aid groups report beginning food deliveries amid the ongoing humanitarian crisis. Ambulance drivers and medical workers describe severe destruction and civilian suffering, with tens of thousands displaced and emergency hospitals overwhelmed.

stories.headline: Russia exported its spies to the West after having them build lives in Brazil
stories.summary: The Russian intelligence officer Artem Shmyrev deceived the West by building a false Brazilian identity with a Brazilian girlfriend, cat, and authentic documents. This was part of a larger spy operation with similar cases uncovered in recent years. Russia used Brazil as a launchpad for some of its most deep-cover operatives, demonstrating the intricate efforts of covert intelligence activity.

stories.headline: Trump picks entrepreneur and Rubio ally Bernie Navarro to be ambassador to Peru
stories.summary: President Donald Trump selected Miami private-equity entrepreneur Bernie Navarro as the U.S. ambassador to Peru. Navarro, praised as a highly respected leader with degrees from the University of Miami and Harvard University, is expected to represent the president with pride and good commitment. His nomination has been confirmed by the Senate among others appointed by Trump this year.

stories.headline: Taking a Beach Day
stories.summary: South Floridians went to South Beach on Memorial Day, enjoying activities such as fishing, which included common large jack crevalle catches along the west coast of Florida, according to the Florida Museum of Natural History.

stories.headline: DeSantis signs bill banning development of golf courses and hotels at state parks
stories.summary: Governor Ron DeSantis signed a bill to prohibit the construction of golf courses, hotels, and other amenities at state parks following a year-long controversy about protecting public land. This move came despite him not responding to email requests before the signing. The bill directly addressed initiatives introduced by his administration concerning park developments in Florida.

stories.headline: Innovative Miami Beach park offers good times and flood protection in rainy times
stories.summary: Miami Beach opened a new park on the site of a former golf course that provides recreational opportunities and serves as a flood protection system. The 19.4-acre Bayshore Park features a design that can handle massive rain events and sea-level rise. Miami Beach’s chief resilience officer highlighted the park as a model for future infrastructure in South Florida to adapt to climate change.

stories.headline: Trump Considers Sanctions On Russia For War
stories.summary: President Trump expressed frustration over new attacks in Ukraine and the slow pace of talks, considering new sanctions against Russia. These sanctions include a potential 30-day cease-fire supported by Ukraine that Russia has so far rejected.

stories.headline: Tariff Truce Spurs 90-Day Rush To Move Products Out of China
stories.summary: Adam Leeb is rushing to ship $700,000 of electronic typewriters from China while the trade truce holds. The 90-day truce agreed between Washington and Beijing this month has brought calm to trade tensions by halting new tariffs, prompting companies to accelerate shipments out of China before tariffs might be reinstated.

stories.headline: Ozempic for Everyone? Doctors Hail ‘GLP-Is’
stories.summary: Doctors are highlighting the benefits of GLP-1 drugs like Ozempic, which help with weight loss and controlling diabetes by spiking water systems in cholesterol-reducing patients. Researchers caution, however, about possible side effects and the need for further studies on long-term impacts.

stories.headline: Bad Year for Cook Keeps Getting Worse
stories.summary: Tim Cook's leadership at Apple faces ongoing challenges as the company's iPhone sales continue to decline amid global regulations, economic pressures, and fierce competition. Analysts note a troubling outlook for Apple, with Cook under pressure due to intensifying market struggles.

stories.headline: Judges Weigh Security Changes
stories.summary: In response to rising tensions and stepped-up criticism from Trump, judges are considering managing their own protections. A federal judicial conference is discussing changes in security protocols amid worries over attacks and threats against judiciary members.

stories.headline: Tributes Are Paid to the Fallen on Memorial Day
stories.summary: A volunteer placed flowers at the gravestones of service members Monday at Arlington National Cemetery to honor fallen soldiers on Memorial Day.

stories.headline: Poll: State’s voters glum over tariffs, economy
stories.summary: A poll conducted by the Detroit Regional Chamber reveals that most registered voters in Michigan are pessimistic about tariffs imposed by President Trump and their impact on the state economy. While about half believe tariffs will have a negative effect, a significant portion either think tariffs will have no impact or declined to answer. The survey highlights a divided electorate on Trump's central policy.

stories.headline: Home values rising in Detroit’s inner ring and beyond
stories.summary: Home values in several neighborhoods around Detroit and its suburbs have shown notable increases between 2024 and 2025. This growth is driven by demand for affordable housing and new construction. Areas like River Rouge, Hazel Park, and Hamtramck have seen some of the biggest rises, with overall regional residential property values increasing significantly.

stories.headline: Uncertainty clouds business in Michigan
stories.summary: Michigan's economy, heavily dependent on the auto industry, faces significant challenges due to political scandals, leadership changes, and uncertain trade and tariff policies under President Donald Trump. The state's economic outlook is increasingly bleak as these factors combine to create a hostile environment for business growth and stability.

stories.headline: King visits Canada after Trump annexation threats
stories.summary: King Charles III made a state visit to Canada following heightened tensions due to U.S. President Donald Trump's comments about annexing parts of Canada. The visit underscores the close ties between Canada and the British monarchy and aims to affirm Canada's sovereignty amid geopolitical uncertainties.

stories.headline: Reserving a glimpse of glory at Yosemite
stories.summary: Yosemite National Park saw a surprisingly busy start to the Memorial Day weekend, with parking challenges caused by a scaled-back and somewhat controversial reservation system introduced last month. Despite initial concerns, operations appeared orderly at the park with cars queued briefly for entry but no cars turned away. Facilities managed the holiday influx well, keeping visitor areas clean and maintaining shuttle service despite busy conditions.

stories.headline: $100M investment set for East Oakland
stories.summary: Carolyn Johnson recalls the hardships of East Oakland's past, but a new initiative called Rise East aims to transform the area over the next decade by focusing on a 40-square-block zone. Backed by a $100 million investment from local nonprofits and community organizations, the initiative will create jobs, affordable housing, improve health and education, and revitalize commercial corridors to combat crime, homelessness, and economic challenges.

stories.headline: Developer plans Dogpatch waterfront park
stories.summary: Developer Enrique Landa has unveiled plans for a new 85-foot-tall residential building and mixed-use project at the power station site in San Francisco's Dogpatch neighborhood. The project will add 105 apartments, 2,600 new homes, commercial space, retail units, a hotel, and a medical research center. Construction is expected to begin this year and complete around October, bringing new amenities and revitalizing the waterfront area.

stories.headline: Hondas, Elantras lead most stolen car brands, models
stories.summary: For the 12th consecutive year, Hondas remain the most frequently stolen car brand in San Francisco. Among models, the Hyundai Elantra is the most stolen, with over 1,200 Honda thefts reported between 2023 and 2024. The report highlights the particular vulnerability of these makes and models to theft in the city, with other cars like Honda Civics and Accords also frequently targeted.

stories.headline: 'Buckle up': Insurers likely to raise rates
stories.summary: Homeowners in California can expect higher insurance rates starting next year, with State Farm planning a 17% increase in 2026 and other insurers following suit due to increased losses from wildfires and regulatory reforms. Experts warn that homeowners will likely bear the brunt of these rising costs, and the impact of imported building auto parts tariffs is also being closely watched.

stories.headline: Cornerstone of capital broadcast news dies at 92
stories.summary: Longtime Sacramento news anchor Stan Atkinson, recognized as a mainstay of Sacramento broadcast news for nearly three decades, died at the age of 92. Atkinson was known for his boots-on-the-ground reporting and charitable work raising millions for regional organizations. He earned legal recognition for his contributions to local news and left a lasting legacy in the community.

stories.headline: Senate fiscal hawks balk at House spending bill
stories.summary: Two of the Senate's staunchest fiscal conservatives expressed skepticism about significant changes to the House spending bill passed last week designed to deliver President Donald Trump's domestic agenda. Senator Ron Johnson noted the precarious path ahead and accused the House of rushing the legislative process, potentially increasing the deficit and urging caution until the Senate has a chance to review and adjust the spending levels responsibly.

stories.headline: In Memorial Day address, Trump takes jab at Biden
stories.summary: President Donald Trump marked Memorial Day with a speech delivered at Arlington National Cemetery, where he criticized the Biden administration, particularly regarding immigration and immigration policy questions. Trump implied doubts about Biden's health and questioned the current administration's governance, intensifying his rhetoric surrounding political and national security issues.

stories.headline: Many retirees push ahead plans to file for Social Security
stories.summary: Following his 67th birthday, Marty McGowan filed for Social Security benefits earlier than planned due to uncertainties caused by the Trump administration's shake-up at the Social Security Administration and broader economic concerns. Data shows an increase in retirees claiming benefits early this fiscal year compared to the previous one. Experts express worries about potential cuts and long-term impacts on the Social Security system, while officials emphasize the complexity of changes and their real-world implications for retirees.

stories.headline: Tampa Bay needs a new courthouse; chief judge wants to build it
stories.summary: The Hillsborough Courthouse Annex in Tampa is facing significant structural and security problems, including flood damage and outdated facilities that do not meet modern court needs. Hillsborough Chief Judge Christopher Sabella and local leaders are working to secure funding for a new courthouse to replace the inadequate Annex, which has ongoing problems affecting judges, staff, and the judicial process.

stories.headline: A very early look at which of Florida's US House races may be competitive
stories.summary: With the 2026 midterm elections approaching, political analysts are assessing Florida's House races for competitiveness. Republicans currently hold a majority of districts, but some races could shift as Democrats target districts previously redrawn in their favor. Analysts note that election outcomes could vary, especially with shifting voter alignments and the influence of former President Trump on primaries and general elections in Florida's key districts.

stories.headline: Many legal abortion clinics are closing
stories.summary: Planned Parenthood of Michigan is shutting down four of its health centers due to financial challenges. The closures come amid broader trends where abortion clinics are shutting down in states that have kept abortion legal but face operational difficulties. This includes the Marquette clinic, the only one providing abortion services in Michigan's Upper Peninsula. The trend reflects difficulties beyond legal restrictions, affecting abortion access where it remains protected by law.

stories.headline: Judge dismisses prison officers' felonies
stories.summary: A judge has dismissed felony charges against four former corrections officers accused in connection with the 2024 beating of an inmate at Ionia prison. The charges included felony assault and misconduct in office. The prosecution's request to send charges to a different court was denied due to lack of evidence that officers had authorized the beating. The inmate also faced charges related to the incident. One officer was sentenced to additional prison time for related assault charges.

stories.headline: Poll: MI voters split on view of economy
stories.summary: A poll by the Detroit Regional Chamber reveals that Michigan voters are divided in their views on the economy, with partisan differences influencing opinions. Forty-three percent of Michigan voters support President Donald Trump's tariffs while 51% oppose them. When categorized by party, 92% of strong Republicans support the tariffs compared to 6% of Democrats. This data highlights deep economic polarization among Michigan voters.

stories.headline: 10 big Detroit buildings that still remain vacant
stories.summary: Private developers in downtown Detroit have made significant progress over the past 20 years filling big and empty buildings, often with great acclaim. However, some large buildings such as the Book Tower, the former Book-Cadillac hotel, the David Whitney Building, and the old Detroit Free Press building still remain vacant or only partially filled. Not every empty downtown building has found its rehab savior, and some structures are expected to remain vacant for the foreseeable future.

stories.headline: A ‘pretty open attack on higher education’
stories.summary: Indiana's state budget proposal could cut hundreds of college degree programs by eliminating over half of the bachelor's degrees offered at public colleges and universities under a new provision requiring strict quotas on program size. This measure threatens diverse academic offerings across institutions such as Purdue University Northwest, Indiana University Kokomo, and University of Southern Indiana. The cuts could significantly impact students and faculty, sparking concern over the future of higher education in the state.

stories.headline: Probe into harassment response wrapping up
stories.summary: An investigation into Indianapolis Mayor Joe Hogsett's handling of sexual harassment complaints made against his former chief of staff Thomas Cook is concluding. The City-County Council’s investigative committee has been reviewing complaints and probing if the mayor's office adequately responded to the allegations and assault complaints. The findings are set to be delivered after a final report from law firm Fisher Phillips, with the investigation highlighting scrutiny over the mayor’s administration response.

stories.headline: DCS worker accused of violating ethics rules
stories.summary: An employee at the Indiana Department of Child Services is accused of providing a residential youth facility with advanced notice of an unannounced inspection, which violated ethics rules. The facility, Pierceton Woods Academy, has a history of sexual abuse allegations. The employee denied confirming the inspection date despite evidence to the contrary. The probe revealed that the worker's tip influenced the inspection process, raising serious ethical concerns.

stories.headline: Activists preserving, sharing U.S. history
stories.summary: Deanna Mitchell, superintendent of the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park, emphasizes the importance of recognizing the stories of enslaved people and preserving American history despite recent controversy over the Trump administration's removal and restoration of historical information concerning abolitionists from federal websites. This issue highlights tensions about how racial injustice, slavery, and lynching history are addressed within the context of diversity, equity, and inclusion policies.

stories.headline: Kelly tries again for trading ban in Congress
stories.summary: Senator Mark Kelly and other Senate Democrats continue efforts to ban members of Congress from trading stocks while in office, amid competing bills and a partisan divide. Republicans have proposed an alternative approach under the PELOSI Act, which aims to separate members from trading decisions. The debate is influenced by recent congressional trading concerns around President Trump's tariff policies, with Democrats calling for investigations into stock market activities and potential insider knowledge.

stories.headline: Migrants relieved as court arrests stop
stories.summary: Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officials made arrests at the Phoenix office building but did not continue operations outside the courtroom for immigration hearings as expected. This sudden halt brought relief to migrants, including a woman from Mexico and a man from Venezuela whose hearing dates fell during the arrests. ICE declined to specifically confirm whether the operation was over or paused, with spokespersons explaining that arrest targets were those the government could deport quickly.

stories.headline: How police caught one prolific thief in St. Louis
stories.summary: Police in St. Louis captured Gage Luttman, a thief responsible for a months-long burglary spree with 240 theft-related charges. Law enforcement used a drone to locate stolen items in a house filled with stolen goods, which Luttman tried to hide by upgrading the house and placing items in the backyard. Luttman was sentenced to 14 years in prison after surveillance and community tips helped officers break the case, highlighting significant law enforcement efforts against property crime.

stories.headline: New aid system operating in Gaza with hunger on the rise
stories.summary: The U.N.-backed Humanitarian Foundation has introduced a new aid delivery system in Gaza after Israeli airstrikes and a blockade have worsened hunger and health conditions for Palestinians. Despite Israeli resistance to this new aid method, the U.N. continues to push for alternative plans to assist Gaza residents. Ongoing conflict and aid delivery challenges raise concerns about the humanitarian situation in the region.

stories.headline: Kehoe asks Trump to OK ‘desperately needed’ aid
stories.summary: Missouri's Governor Mike Kehoe has urged President Donald Trump to approve a major disaster declaration to provide federal aid to Missouri counties affected by severe storms and flooding. The request is meant to help deal with debris removal, repairs, and support for impacted residents. The disaster declaration would activate federal resources through the National Guard and support long-term recovery efforts in the affected areas.

stories.headline: Top Chefs Adapt to New Realities
stories.summary: Chef Mike Randolph and other top chefs in St. Louis are adapting their restaurants to the evolving food scene by embracing pared-down menus, efficient labor, and casual dining experiences. Randolph, after closing his Püblico restaurant, is now focusing on a new establishment, Nettie's Pizza Den, that emphasizes smaller menus and direct customer ordering, reflecting a broader shift in culinary business models due to changing consumer preferences and economic realities.

stories.headline: Venezuelan family seeks asylum amid court battle
stories.summary: Following the revocation of legal protections for many Venezuelans in the U.S., a family that fled political persecution in Venezuela and sought refuge in Minnesota is now embroiled in a court battle to maintain their asylum status. The case highlights the challenges faced by Venezuelan immigrants amidst shifting U.S. immigration policies.

stories.headline: Protesters see Vietnam-era parallels
stories.summary: Activists and veterans drew comparisons between anti-Trump administration protests and those against the Vietnam War, highlighting continued concerns regarding cuts to Veterans Affairs and the impact on veterans’ benefits and services. Speakers emphasized the importance of solidarity and activism in response to current political actions.

stories.headline: Reflecting on their sacrifice
stories.summary: A Vietnam War veteran shared his reflections 50 years after the fall of Saigon on Memorial Day, emphasizing the importance of honoring veterans regardless of the unpopularity of wars. The veteran spoke about his struggles with mental illness and the need to recognize the trauma experienced by service members. Memorial Day events included honoring fallen soldiers and acknowledging their sacrifices.

stories.headline: Tornado myth is wishful thinking
stories.summary: Meteorologist Paul Douglas addressed misconceptions about tornadoes, clarifying that tornados do strike urban areas, despite common beliefs that they largely affect rural areas. The article highlighted recent tornados in Minnesota and neighboring states, and the debunking of myths regarding tornado frequency and locations.

stories.headline: A powerful voice for Black America, Harlem
stories.summary: The late Rep. Charles Rangel, a pioneering African American congressman from New York's Harlem, passed away. He was known for his long and outspoken career advocating for civil rights and representing a diverse constituency in Manhattan and the Bronx. Rangel's death marks the loss of a significant figure in American politics and civil rights history.

stories.headline: PEDIATRIC CLINIC’S CLOSURE LEADS TO LONG WAITLISTS
stories.summary: The closure of MaineGeneral Health’s Edmund Ervin Pediatric Center in Augusta has left many families struggling to access diagnostic services for their children. Parents report difficulties getting crucial diagnoses and treatments for conditions like developmental disabilities, as primary care doctors often lack the necessary expertise. Advocates are urging restoration of these services to prevent long-term impacts on affected children.

stories.headline: Maine lawmakers want to examine how judges are disciplined. Judicial branch says it’s not their call.
stories.summary: The Maine Legislature is debating efforts to investigate how disciplinary actions against judges are handled, particularly following an ethics complaint against Supreme Court Justice Catherine Connors. While legislators seek to close gaps in the judicial branch’s accountability system, the judicial branch maintains that it holds exclusive authority over judicial discipline, citing constitutional separation of powers and concerns about legislative overreach.

stories.headline: Who will Maine Democrats run against Susan Collins next year?
stories.summary: As the 2026 election approaches, many expect Governor Janet Mills to decide on her political plans, while other leaders consider a Senate run. With several high-profile Democrats entering the race, the party is evaluating who can best challenge Senator Susan Collins, but uncertainties remain as some potential candidates remain noncommittal about their intentions.

stories.headline: Rep. Golden and LePage matchup likely to be ‘barnburner’
stories.summary: Maine’s 2nd District is shaping up for a highly competitive election as incumbent U.S. Rep. Jared Golden faces a probable challenge from former Governor Paul LePage. Both politicians hold significant support bases in the district, setting up a collision course that could have national political consequences. Party members see this race as a key battle that could influence the upcoming midterm elections and control of the U.S. House of Representatives.

stories.headline: Ukrainian refugees plan their Alaska exits
stories.summary: About a dozen Ukrainians who fled war and resettled in Alaska are facing the expiration of their two-year humanitarian parole terms under a U.S. government program initiated in 2023. With parole renewal applications stalled, many are urgently planning their departures or uncertain futures. One refugee, Inha Fozekosh, purchased tickets to leave Alaska for Germany and highlighted the ongoing stress of living in limbo. Zori Opanasevych, who directs the nonprofit assisting Ukrainian relocations, noted a growing number of families planning to exit after initially arriving in 2023.

stories.headline: Trump honors fallen soldiers
stories.summary: President Donald Trump paid tribute to fallen service members during a Memorial Day ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery, honoring the 'great, great warriors.' Despite his critical remarks about the Biden administration and judges who blocked some initiatives, Trump commemorated the sacrifice of around 400,000 service members buried at Arlington and acknowledged Gold Star families. He emphasized reverence for their legacy and saluted them in his Memorial Day address.

stories.headline: LaFrance administration aims to set up 24 ‘microunits’ in pilot program for homeless
stories.summary: Mayor Suzanne LaFrance’s administration announced plans to create 24 'microunits' for homeless residents in a pilot housing program in the Tudor and Elmore roads area. The initiative involves using municipal land to provide shelter and essential services to homeless individuals struggling to find housing. Special assistant Thea Agnew described the project as realistic and urgent, with detailed plans being prepared by the housing and Homelessness Committee. The goal is to allow immediate access to transitional living and treatment for people experiencing homelessness.

stories.headline: King Charles III arrives in Canada to underscore nation's sovereignty after Trump annexation threats
stories.summary: King Charles III arrived in Canada on a state visit intended to affirm the nation's sovereignty amid recent tensions following former President Trump’s discussion of annexing parts of Canada. The visit by the British monarch aims to strengthen ties with Canada and emphasize the enduring bond of constitutional monarchy despite political differences and concerns over U.S. intentions. The visit comes as Prime Minister Mark Carney prepares to outline his government's agenda to the new Parliament.

stories.headline: FEMA delay stings after Cave City hit
stories.summary: Veda Rose Knappenberger reported damage from a tornado hitting Cave City, including injuries and severe property damage. Residents face delays in emergency response and aid, with FEMA working to fill infrastructure gaps. Concerns remain over the pace and adequacy of disaster assistance for those affected, highlighting the challenges faced following natural disasters.

stories.headline: Trump honors fallen at Arlington Cemetery
stories.summary: President Donald Trump paid tribute to fallen service members during a Memorial Day ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery. He praised the sacrifices of military personnel and reaffirmed his commitment to honoring their legacy and the nation. The event highlighted the solemn respect for those who served and died for the country.

stories.headline: Essential Air Service cuts eyed
stories.summary: The Trump administration's budget threatens to cut funding for Essential Air Service that supports four Arkansas airports. These cuts could lead to reduced flights and significantly impact local businesses and communities that rely on air connectivity. Local officials and representatives are concerned about the economic and accessibility consequences of these potential cuts.

stories.headline: Aid distribution begins in Gaza amid airstrikes
stories.summary: A new aid system commenced distribution of food to Palestinians in Gaza despite ongoing Israeli airstrikes that have killed at least 52 people. The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation is managing aid delivery amid a blockade and continued tensions. The U.S. and U.N. have pushed for expanded aid access as Israel demands an end to Hamas control over aid supplies.

stories.headline: Russian aerial assault on Ukraine continues
stories.summary: Russia launched its biggest drone attack against Ukraine, escalating the bombing campaign that aims for a breakthrough in ending the three-year-old war. Despite several major attacks and increased air bombardments, Ukraine and its allies continue to resist and push back. The assault is part of a broader effort by Russia to capture more Ukrainian territory and counter U.S.-led peace efforts.

stories.headline: Slammed by Russia, Ukraine seeks more U.S. Patriots
stories.summary: Amid worldwide demand and slow production of air defense systems, Ukraine is seeking more U.S. Patriot missile defense systems as it faces ballistic missile attacks from Russia. These missiles are difficult to intercept but are critical in Ukraine's defense. The Biden administration is cautious about sending more to avoid antagonizing Russia. Ukraine’s need for missile defense was apparent over Memorial Day weekend when Russian forces launched missile attacks, some targeting Kyiv. Patriot units are believed to be stationed there, with ongoing support from the U.S. and its allies.

stories.headline: E. COLI OUTBREAK SICKENED DOZENS, BUT NO ALERTS MADE
stories.summary: An E. coli outbreak in Southern Indiana sickened at least 90 people, many of them children, and caused the death of one 9-year-old boy. The outbreak was linked to contaminated romaine lettuce. Despite the seriousness of the outbreak, food safety inspections and public notifications were scaled back, which limited awareness and response to the contamination. The incident has raised concerns about food safety oversight and regulatory responses to such outbreaks.

stories.headline: Delco health department faces tests
stories.summary: Delaware County's health department is facing challenges and legal battles related to restaurant inspections after new operational changes established in 2022. The changes aimed at better disease outbreak prevention and immunization campaigns have caused tensions with local towns over restaurant sanitation and inspection standards. The agency has been working to improve health inspections amid competing demands and legal pressures sparked by the creation of a new health department.

stories.headline: A time to remember
stories.summary: In Philadelphia, a missing Vietnam War Marine is among those honored at Memorial Day services at Penn's Landing. The story focuses on the search for Carlos Ashlock, a Marine who disappeared in action after a 1967 firefight in Vietnam. Family members, including Major Ashlock and members of the Ashlock-Adams family, attended the service. Despite efforts by the government, Carlos Ashlock remains missing, and his family continues to seek answers and maintain his case.

stories.headline: More state forest found 'suitable' for solar by DNR
stories.summary: State officials reviewed at least five sites across northern Michigan for possible solar energy buildout in what’s becoming a controversial effort to increase renewable energy by deforesting state land. Many and other documents revealed the DNR found previously unknown areas in the Mackinaw and Pere Marquette state forests to be suitable to lease for solar panels in 2021, despite concerns over deforestation and public outcry. The DNR has not reassessed sites after an ongoing pause on utility-scale solar on state land. Some areas, including parcels near Gaylord and Roscommon, are already under contract with developers, and state officials said leasing for solar is part of increasing revenue for agencies and accelerating Michigan's goal of 100% clean energy by 2040.

stories.headline: Bill would make it illegal to pass school buses flashing yellow
stories.summary: Lawmakers want to close a gap in Michigan law that allows drivers to pass school buses preparing to pick up or drop off children by flashing yellow lights. A House committee advanced a bill that would require motorists to immediately slow and then stop at least 20 feet away from any school bus with flashing yellow lights, prohibiting proceeding until the bus starts moving or flashing lights turn off. Violators would face fines between $100 and $500. The current law was written when school buses only had red lights, causing safety concerns. Michigan State Police have issued guidance to drivers to slow at amber lights to promote children's safety.

stories.headline: Indy 500 champ
stories.summary: Two-time defending IndyCar series champion Alex Palou won his first Indianapolis 500 Sunday. The series is set to continue in Michigan this weekend for the Detroit Grand Prix.

stories.headline: Trump extends deadline for tariffs on EU goods to July 9
stories.summary: President Donald Trump announced an extension of the deadline for imposing 50% tariffs on EU goods from June 1 to July 9, following discussions with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. The pause comes amid ongoing negotiations and attempts to resolve disputes over reciprocal tariffs and trade issues between the U.S. and EU.

stories.headline: Leavenworth lawsuit against CoreCivic dismissed by judge
stories.summary: A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit that challenged CoreCivic's plan to build a private prison in Leavenworth. The lawsuit aimed to stop the company from opening a detention center without necessary permissions but was rejected by the U.S. District Court. CoreCivic had agreed to local zoning rules, and the company can proceed with its plans. The city is expected to appeal the decision.

stories.headline: Kansas braces for fight over Supreme Court direct election
stories.summary: Kansas faces a political battle over whether to switch to a merit-based system for selecting Supreme Court justices or maintain direct elections. The fight comes as Republicans push a model to limit the influence of billionaires and political party control, while opponents warn such changes could diminish judicial independence. The debate highlights tensions on how justices are chosen and their accountability to voters.

stories.headline: Salvadorans seen as undeterred by Trump’s policies
stories.summary: In El Salvador, despite President Trump's administration's strict immigration policies and increased deportations to the U.S., many Salvadorans remain determined to migrate for better opportunities. Interviews with Salvadoran migrants reveal that while challenges and risks have increased, hopes for a better life continue to motivate migration attempts. Experts and migrants alike recognize limited opportunities in El Salvador but acknowledge ongoing efforts to improve conditions. The article highlights the complex interplay between immigration policy and human aspirations.

stories.headline: Charles to underscore Canada’s sovereignty
stories.summary: King Charles III visited Ottawa to emphasize Canada’s sovereignty amidst U.S. President Donald Trump’s talk of annexing northern neighbors. The visit underscores the importance of maintaining national identities and political independence despite pressures or discussions at the international level.

stories.headline: US-backed aid group starts in Gaza
stories.summary: A new aid system in Gaza, supported by the U.S., distributed goods to Palestinians facing hunger due to ongoing blockades. The initiative comes amid ongoing conflict, aiming to provide humanitarian relief in a region severely impacted by the blockade and conflict. This effort represents an important step in addressing basic needs amid a complex geopolitical situation.

stories.headline: Kooper’s Tavern to open in Havre de Grace
stories.summary: Kooper’s Tavern, a popular Falls Point establishment known for its unique culture, is expanding to a third location in Harford County, specifically Havre de Grace. The new site follows continued success and a nod from Zagat for its service. The opening aims to bring the tavern’s atmosphere and offerings to a broader Maryland audience.

stories.headline: Trump pays tribute to fallen soldiers
stories.summary: President Donald Trump honored fallen service members during a Memorial Day ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery. Trump commemorated U.S. service members and Gold Star families while emphasizing respect and remembrance. Despite controversies and his usual political rhetoric, Trump solemnly paid tribute, reflecting on sacrifice and patriotism. He also criticized political opponents but expressed a commitment to honoring military legacy and sacrifices made by American soldiers.

stories.headline: Dems ponder party's future after defeats
stories.summary: The Democratic Party suffered significant setbacks in 2024 and early 2025 elections, including losing both chambers of Congress and the primary election bid of President Joe Biden. Party leaders, experts, and members are analyzing the direction the party should take moving forward, especially ahead of the 2026 midterm races. Discussions focus on internal divisions and how to cope with a more centrist voter base. The party is considering whether to shift strategies or maintain current leadership as it prepares for future elections.

stories.headline: Black leaders see politics at play in reparations veto
stories.summary: Maryland Governor Wes Moore vetoed a bill related to reparations payments for descendants of slaves, drawing criticism from some Black leaders in Baltimore. The vetoed Senate Bill 587 proposed a two-year study on whether reparations should be paid considering the state's history of slavery and inequality. While some leaders, including The Rev. Dr. Robert Turner, expressed disappointment, citing a need to address historic injustices, Governor Moore felt it was not yet time for such a study. The bill's fate highlights ongoing debates on reparations and racial justice in Maryland.

stories.headline: Police to boost summer patrols
stories.summary: As summer approaches, the Baltimore Police Department plans to increase its presence in popular entertainment areas around the city. The department's summer crime initiatives include deploying more officers for major holidays and high-profile events to ensure public safety. Residents and visitors can expect more patrols downtown, Ft. Inner Harbor, Fell's Point, Federal Hill, and other locations. Plans for increased presence will continue as weather warms and more public events occur, aimed particularly at young people gathering in public spaces where past incidents have happened.

stories.headline: Crossings at border take a sharp decline
stories.summary: Border Patrol agents report a significant drop in encounters with migrants at the U.S.-Mexico border in southern New Mexico compared to the previous fiscal year. Agent Claudio Herrera notes that the average daily apprehensions have decreased from 60-70 individuals to about 2,700 monthly. This decline follows President Donald Trump's crackdown on illegal migration, reflecting changes in border enforcement and smuggling activity.

stories.headline: Louisiana jailbreak spurs calls for action
stories.summary: Following a jailbreak of about 10 inmates from a jail in New Orleans, residents and officials express frustration and concern over ongoing public safety issues. Neighborhoods affected report increased tension, with some escapees still at large. Law enforcement agencies have increased efforts, with rewards offered for tips leading to apprehensions, yet fears of violence and disorder persist as the community seeks accountability.

stories.headline: Trump honors troops' 'ultimate sacrifice'
stories.summary: President Donald Trump delivered a history-laden Memorial Day speech at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, honoring more than 400,000 veterans and their families. His remarks commemorated the 250th anniversary of the American Revolutionary War and paid tribute to the bravery of colonists in historic battles. The speech carried a somber tone, contrasting with the long holiday weekend's political tensions.

stories.headline: Trump critical of Putin, but resists imposing new sanctions
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has openly criticized Russian President Vladimir Putin for the recent large-scale bombing of Ukrainian cities but has refrained from imposing new sanctions. Trump highlighted his good personal relationship with Putin and expressed concerns about the impact of harsher sanctions, leading to mixed reactions about his approach to the Ukraine conflict.

stories.headline: Trump limit on COVID shots leaves many anxious
stories.summary: The Trump administration's policy restricting the approval of coronavirus vaccines only for high-risk groups has raised concerns among Americans, especially parents and caregivers of vulnerable individuals. Critics worry that limiting COVID-19 shots could leave many without adequate protection amid the ongoing pandemic.

stories.headline: Elon effect is still hurting Tesla sales in state
stories.summary: Rude protests and vandalism related to Elon Musk and President Donald Trump's influence have negatively impacted Tesla sales in Washington state. Some Tesla owners and residents report decreased enthusiasm for EVs, with a campaign against Musk's role in Trump's administration contributing to this decline. The sentiments reflect ongoing political and social tensions affecting consumer behavior.

stories.headline: Russia launches largest drone bombardment in Ukraine war
stories.summary: Russia has launched its largest drone attack against Ukraine, marking a significant escalation in the conflict. Despite an ongoing 30-day ceasefire proposed by the U.S., Moscow has continued aerial bombings, pushing Ukrainian defenses to their limits. The attack prompted strong criticism from U.S. President Donald Trump towards Russian leader Vladimir Putin for escalating the war.

stories.headline: South Seattle food hub canceled over federal funding uncertainty
stories.summary: Food Lifeline's planned South Seattle food hub, initially expected to open in fall 2026 and funded by a $4 million federal grant, has been canceled due to funding uncertainty and concerns over President Donald Trump's administration. The cancellation has raised concerns among food aid groups and King County officials who have pushed for a food hub to address food insecurity exacerbated by the pandemic and a growing tenant deficit in warehouse space.

stories.headline: Kids of divorce have higher chances of jail, study says
stories.summary: A new study finds that U.S. children whose parents divorce before age 5 have higher chances of incarceration later in life. The study shows that halved family splits into two households reduce income growth opportunities. Key factors include financial resources loss, neighborhood quality decline, and diminished parental involvement. The study suggests these family changes significantly affect children's outcomes more than isolated divorce effects.

stories.headline: Trump’s Russia strategy creates void
stories.summary: President Donald Trump recently criticized Russian President Vladimir Putin, calling him "absolutely CRAZY" amid ongoing criticism of Russian actions in Ukraine. Trump’s comments followed a week of large bombings in Ukrainian cities, which occurred days after a two-hour call between Trump and Putin. Trump has a history of expressing a "good relationship" with Putin but recent events have led to a strategic void in America’s approach to Russia, with some government officials noting a familiar pattern in Trump’s stance.

stories.headline: 50 years after the Vietnam war, ‘the Wall’ in nation’s capital reflects on America’s trauma
stories.summary: The Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington, D.C., known as 'the Wall,' continues to draw millions of visitors annually. The black granite slabs are inscribed with over 58,000 names of fallen soldiers from Vietnam, Cambodia, and Laos wars spanning 1958-1975. The memorial is a place of remembrance and healing, with stories from veterans like Karl Marlantes, who saw 93 Marines’ names on the wall. The monument represents unexplainable power and emotional connection for veterans and visitors alike.

stories.headline: Eastdale drawing interest
stories.summary: The state of Tennessee is considering a 162-acre property in Eastdale as a potential site for the new Moccasin Bend Mental Health Institute. The land, owned by Ashish Chaudhari and located off Tunnel Boulevard across from New United Missionary Baptist Church, is heavily wooded and backs up to South Chickamauga Creek. The property is marked with "Danger" and "Keep Out" signs due to a collapsing pile of cement bricks and other hazards visible from the road.

stories.headline: Deep in the delta, a menace lurks
stories.summary: In Shaw, Mississippi, Stephanie Smith and other residents face health challenges caused by poor sanitation due to inadequate sewage systems. Anthropology research reveals the link between environmental factors, poverty, and a range of health issues for both adults and children in the community. Smith's experience sheds light on the struggles of families dealing with persistent water and health problems.

stories.headline: Photos help develop traffic safety picture
stories.summary: Ari Iaccarino, a Somerville resident, has spent two years documenting car crashes at Mystic Valley Parkway and Boston Avenue. His observations highlight common causes such as reckless left turns and combinations of car movements that contribute to collisions, offering valuable insights to improve traffic safety in the area.

stories.headline: Russia once again intensifies air assault
stories.summary: Russia has launched its largest drone attack against Ukraine recently, escalating its bombing campaign in an effort to break the stalemate in the 3-year-old conflict. This offensive involves significant aerial bombardments and signals Russia's determination to capture more Ukrainian territory despite peace efforts and an unconditioned 30-day cease-fire proposed by Kyiv and the United States that Moscow rejected.

stories.headline: Dairy doubts: 'Who's going to milk the cows?'
stories.summary: Dustin Machia, a fifth-generation dairy farmer in northern Vermont, voices concerns about the impact of increased deportations of migrant farmworkers on local agriculture. Farm owners near the Canadian border, like Machia, are anxious about labor shortages as immigration enforcement intensifies, with recent releases ordered for some detained workers.

stories.headline: Museum expands footprint
stories.summary: The Heinz History Center is set to expand with a new addition that will house a large cauldron used to make steel located at its Penn Avenue site in the Strip District. The expansion work will begin soon and the center aims for completion by 2028, enhancing its capacity and display facilities for historical artifacts.

stories.headline: 'I'M HERE TO REMEMBER' - Lawrenceville parade marks a day of solemnity and fun
stories.summary: The annual Memorial Day parade in Lawrenceville honored veterans and those who served during the Vietnam War with a parade and solemn ceremonies. Veterans and community members participated in remembrance activities including speeches and laying of wreaths at Allegheny Cemetery.

stories.headline: Russia escalates bombing campaign
stories.summary: Russia launched its biggest drone attack against Ukraine, escalating its bombing campaign despite international calls for peace. This intensification undermines hopes for an end to the ongoing 3-year conflict, following rejected ceasefire proposals and continued heavy fighting in the region.

stories.headline: Will the NFL draft deliver?
stories.summary: Local officials in Pittsburgh are weighing the potential economic impact and exposure from hosting next year's NFL draft, which is expected to attract significant crowds and drive marketing for the region. Past host cities have seen boosts in visitation and hotel stays, but the true payoff remains uncertain as projections vary and benefits depend on various factors.

stories.headline: Texas House restricts DEI in public schools
stories.summary: The Texas House passed a Senate bill aimed at limiting diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives in public school hiring and training. The policy aligns with the Legislature's 2023 ban on DEI in public universities. Dubbed 'parental rights bill,' Senate Bill 12 seeks to tighten parental notification and consent concerning subjects like mental health and physical health, among others. The legislation also reflects ongoing efforts to restrict DEI measures, following the effects of a 2023 law that led to layoffs and altered equity-based student support practices in higher education.

stories.headline: One of nation’s best chefs joins MML Hospitality
stories.summary: A nationally recognized chef has joined MML Hospitality, signifying a notable addition to the company's culinary leadership. This move is expected to enhance MML Hospitality's offerings and reputation in the competitive hospitality industry by leveraging the chef's expertise and acclaim.

stories.headline: House OKs measure to overhaul TX Lottery
stories.summary: The Texas House approved a bipartisan measure to overhaul the Texas Lottery, endorsing the Senate's initiative to abolish the state agency's governing board. The change aims to place the $8 billion-a-year gaming enterprise under a different state branch to improve oversight. The 112-27 vote reflects efforts to combat alleged rogue behavior and unsavory practices within lottery operations. The legislation presents an alternative to abolishing the 33-year-old lottery and offers a chance for rehabilitation of the system, according to Rep. Charlie Geren.

stories.headline: MISSED INDICTMENTS
stories.summary: Travis County prosecutors frequently failed to indict suspects within the mandatory 90-day period, leading to suspects remaining in jail longer. The article highlights the case of a 19-year-old Austin Community College student who spent 35 days in jail at the Travis County Correctional Complex after filing a letter explaining that detention posed a threat to his future. Despite his explanation and enrollment in dental hygiene school, prosecutorial delays left him incarcerated. Thirteen days after release, prosecutors dropped the case, exemplifying broader systemic failures in prompt indictments.

stories.headline: Scientists track diabetic nerve pain
stories.summary: Researchers at the University of Texas at Dallas have uncovered clues to the puzzling nerve pain experienced by diabetic patients, identifying nerve root ganglia clusters that relay sensory signals like pain to the brain as a major factor. The findings, published in Nature Communications, could advance understanding and treatments of diabetic peripheral neuropathy and related chronic pain.

stories.headline: Maps could reshape politics
stories.summary: A Republican-driven plan to redraw Tarrant County's legislative boundaries would grant the GOP a supermajority on the Commissioners Court by moving Black voters from a majority-minority district into a predominantly Black district. Critics argue the plan is discriminatory and could lead to legal challenges, urging Commissioners to delay redistricting until after the 2030 census to ensure fair representation.

stories.headline: 'Great warriors'
stories.summary: President Donald Trump honored fallen soldiers on Memorial Day by placing a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier and saluting alongside Vice President JD Vance and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth. Trump called the soldiers 'great, great warriors,' reflecting on their sacrifices and the solemnity of the occasion at Arlington National Cemetery.

stories.headline: Ban on sex abuse NDAs moves along
stories.summary: Texas legislators are advancing a bill preventing non-disclosure agreements (NDAs) from silencing sexual abuse survivors. The legislation, supported by victims and backed by Senate Bill 835, aims to prohibit NDAs in cases of sexual assault and child sexual abuse. The bill is nearing final approval after gaining strong backing from lawmakers including Senate leaders and Governor Greg Abbott.

stories.headline: House approves bill to save Texas Lottery
stories.summary: The Texas House has passed a compromise bill with a 110-29 vote on second reading to shift control of the Texas Lottery from the commission to the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation. The bill, authored by State Rep. Charlie Geren, seeks to ensure continued operation without disruption, providing about $2 billion annually for public education and $27 million annually for veterans.

stories.headline: Trial set to begin for accused killer of Sade Robinson
stories.summary: Maxwell Anderson, 34, is charged with the first-degree intentional homicide and mutilation of college student Sade Carleena Robinson, 19, who was dismembered in April 2024. Anderson has been in custody since his arrest in April but failed to post bond. The trial is set to begin May 27, with jury selection underway. A human arm and other bones were found near Lake Michigan, linked to the case. Anderson will be prosecuted by district attorney Ian Vance-Curzan. The trial involves multiple witnesses, police officers, and forensic experts.

stories.headline: Senators pressure SDC over its status
stories.summary: Wisconsin state senators LaTonya Johnson and Dora Drake, along with Rep. Kalan Haywood, are urging the Social Development Commission (SDC) to relinquish its designation as a community action agency to avoid risking $1.18 million in federal Community Services Block Grant funds. The deadline for decision is Sept. 30. The senators argue that without this designation, the department can better address anti-poverty programs in Milwaukee County, while the SDC has not offered services since April 2024 and the situation places funding and access to services at risk.

stories.headline: Showing the middle way
stories.summary: Milwaukee is encouraged to pursue more mid-tier housing construction, drawing lessons from other Midwestern cities like Green Bay and Des Moines. Green Bay is supporting workforce housing targeting people earning 80% to 120% of the area median income, while Des Moines provides tax benefits for buildings with two to 12 units. Milwaukee's Mayor and Common Council have made moves to create more workforce and missing middle housing, but developers and residents feel the efforts fall short and favor absentee landlords.

stories.headline: Medical researchers at UIC, Northwestern reeling from funding cuts under Trump
stories.summary: Medical researchers at the University of Illinois Chicago and Northwestern University are struggling due to funding cuts implemented under the Trump administration, impacting ongoing research projects and university resources.

stories.headline: Vets, families and officials reflect on Memorial Day at Grant Park ceremony
stories.summary: Army veteran Gary Higgins stands with his wife during the 29th Annual Maj. Gen. John A. Logan Memorial Day Commemoration at Grant Park, where veterans, families, and officials came together to honor and reflect on Memorial Day.

stories.headline: Get up to speed on city's new cameras
stories.summary: Starting Sunday, 16 new speed cameras will start issuing fines across the city, with 11 more coming soon after. This report details where motorists need to slow down or pay the price for speeding violations.
